comments.content:
The caption to these photos reads

_Photos about typography on the 200dpi OLPC screen._

**200dpi**

This was news to me, because I guess I hadn’t been paying much attention to the display side of the OLPC story. Oh, and apparently the subpixel stripes are diagonal. Very cool.

This rather supports the theory that the reason screen displays have not improved in resolution as anticipated ten years ago is that most commercial software doesn’t scale well, not because of inherent difficulty or cost in making higher resolution screens.

The 200dpi may be a bit misleading as it includes subpixels (so I hear) so in color mode it may be a bit less. Anyway I think the type holds up pretty well even down to small sizes, as I think the screen shots seem to show.

Nice.  
200dpi? Wow. Can we get some really good macro shots?

But what’s cool about a diagonal subpixel stripe?  
Who makes 45-degree Italics? :-) To me it seems  
like a concession to images (think of TVs).

\> This rather supports the theory that ...

Nah. The commercial software would have scaled well if there was a financial incentive. This instead is evidence that the reason we haven’t had hi-res screens is simply that there’s no money in it - people don’t want to pay for readability, because they don’t really grasp what readability is (since, unlike legibility\*, it’s subconscious). The telling difference between OLPC and the commercial world is that the former has a philanthropic core...

\* Think 1-bit sans letterforms.

hhp

Huh? Exactly how does “200dpi” include subpixels?  
You mean it’s less than 70dpi?!  
Or 200 / sqroot(3) = ~120 dpi?

hhp

_But what’s cool about a diagonal subpixel stripe?_

Uniform x and y direction resolution enhancement. It happens that Latin italics tend to have slant angles that benefit particularly from vertical subpixel stripes, but there are other aspects of Latin letterforms that do not benefit from that arrangement, and then of course there is the whole wide world of other writing systems in which there is a great diversity of strokes and bowls to be accomodated. Providing uniform x and y resolution enhancement accomodates more things better than x direction only. The rendering of Latin italics might not be as good — but at 200 dpi, who is going to notice? —, but many other things should be better (Arabic, for example, and other writing systems with strong horizontal features and shallow curves).

_Exactly how does “200dpi” include subpixels?_

I didn’t say it did. I don’t know what the native resolution is. As I said, this is news to me. Do a Google search on olpc 200dpi for more information.

\> Providing uniform x and y resolution enhancement  
\> accomodates more things better than x direction only.

I’m not sure.  
Do note that most “writing” is horizontal (in more ways than one).

My gut feeling is that uniformity is a lost opportunity.  
But my gut has been wrong before.

\> I didn’t say it did.

I didn’t say you did. :-) Simon did.

But especially since the subpixels are on a diagonal there’s no indication as to how it’s really being measured. Also, I’m confused about this monochrome/color difference, especially when it comes to factoring in the subpixeling...

hhp

\>I didn’t say you did. :-) Simon did.

It’s what I heard someone say so was clearly hear-say.

Also off-list I was asked what the MS fonts were doing on the Open Source device. Alex asked me if he could install them on there for his demo (as they have lovely Greeks) and I said okay.

Cheers, Si
